description: A comparative exploration of the fundamental aspects of Near Eastern societies over a broad temporal and geographic scope.  Primary sources will be used to analyze social structures, and institutions of the peoples of the ancient Near East including the Levant.
title: Ancient Near Eastern Societies
subject: NES

description: An examination of the world views and spirituality of various Near Eastern societies on the basis of their literary record.  Documents such as prayers, incantations, rituals, and literature will be explored with a view to determining how peoples of various ancient Near Eastern societies felt about themselves, their environment, and each other.
title: Ancient Near Eastern Philosophy and Spirituality
subject: NES

description: An investigation of cultic practices based on textual sources and archaeological evidence, along with various theoretical approaches to cult in context. Individual research will evaluate the resources available and design models to put various cults in their full symbolic, architectural, and geographical contexts as one component of the diverse cultures of the ancient Levant and eastern Mediterranean world.
title: Temples and Sanctuaries in the Eastern Mediterranean World
subject: NES

description: A study of the myths of the Underworld expressing various views of the Afterlife is put in dialogue with the archaeological evidence of actual burial customs among different cultural and ethnic groups in the Near East and the broader Mediterranean world.
title: Myth and Burial Customs in the Ancient Near East
subject: NES

description: A study of the myths of the Underworld expressing various views of the Afterlife is put in dialogue with the archaeological evidence of actual burial customs among different cultural and ethnic groups in the Near East and the broader Mediterranean world.
title: Myth and Burial Customs in the Ancient Near East
subject: NES

description: An introduction to Old Babylonian language, including the development of cuneiform, study of cuneiform script and Old Babylonian grammar, and the 'classical' dialect of the language.  Students will read influential royal documents in the original.
title: Old Babylonian Royal Inscriptions
subject: NES

description: This course will continue from NES 621.  Readings will be taken from the Babylonian chancery of Hammurapi, various local economic records, and literary materials such as myth, magical texts, and the like.
title: Old Babylonian Administrative Documents and Literature
subject: NES

description: A selection of material from one author or several authors or investigation of selected themes, topics, genres at the graduate level.
title: Special Topics
subject: NES
